Description: Fragment of a wheel-made pottery sanctuary lamp: everted flange with an incurved raised rim with an everted lip. Three wick-holes remain. The flange is notched. Decorated with a brown slip, with an orange band on the interior. Fine buff-grey reduced fabric with very fine mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Several sanctuary lamps were found in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Gardner 1888, 48; British Museum GR 1888,0601.151.a-c; 1888,0601.151.d-e; 1888,0601.151.f; 1888,0601.151.g), or were subsequently attributed to the Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Bailey 1977, previously unregistered in the British Museum GR 1965,0930.884-885; GR 1965,0930.882; 1965,0930.883; 1965,0930.881; 1965,0930.880; 1965,0930.877; 1965,0930.878; 1965,0930.879; 1965,0930.888; 1965,0930.889-891; 1965,0930.892; 1965,0930.886; 1965,0930.887). A variety of Egyptian, Ephesian (Bailey 1977, Q 153, Q154) and Rhodian (ibid, 365, 370) sanctuary lamp types haev been found at Naukratis. Similar sanctuary lamps have been found at Athens (Howland 1958, Type 143), the sanctuary of Hemithea at Kastabos (Cook and Plommer 1966, 55-6, pl. 9) and the sanctuary of Demeter, Knossos (Coldstream 1973, pls 13, 15 and 26). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton. Cook, J. M. and Plommer, W. H. 1966. The Sanctuary of Hemithea at Kastabos, Cambridge. Coldstream, J. N. 1973. Knossos, the Sanctuary of Demeter, London.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q365)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KA.09) (Phase 1)
